headline: Sen. Raphael Warnock proposes slashing gas, drug, and shipping costs to beat inflation ahead of a midterm challenge from MAGA
author: Warren Rojas
sentences: The freshman lawmaker, who is on the ballot in Georgia this fall in a closely-contested presidential swing state, proposed pouncing on the rising prices Americans are faced with when filling up their vehicles, picking up groceries, or adding basic necessities to online orders.

"It is mind boggling to me that pharmaceutical companies get to tell the taxpayer how much of their money they're going to take," he told reporters, adding that "it's outrageous that you cannot negotiate the cost of prescription drugs."

Warnock's seat is one of a handful of "Toss-up" races the political handicappers at FiveThirtyEight wrote could decide control of a narrowly split chamber where Democrats' trump card is Vice President Kamala Harris' tie-breaking vote.

Defusing inflationary fears before the November elections requires easing the financial squeeze average Americans feel every time they open their wallets, Sen. Raphael Warnock advised Democratic leaders in Washington, DC.
The newly minted lawmaker is likely to face off against former professional football star Herschel Walker — one of many Republican political newcomers Trump has endorsed in races around the country.
Democratic strategists have warned that the party will be annihilated in the midterm elections if they don't start to pivot to an economic message that resonates with, and gives voters hope.
Mark Kelly of Arizona, Maggie Hassan of New Hampshire, and Catherine Cortez Masto of Nevada, in proposing a temporary gas tax holiday that would save people money while at the pump.

Democratic Sen. Raphael Warnock of Georgia speaks to members of the press after a Senate Democratic Caucus meeting on January 18, 2022, in Washington, DC.
Warnock also wrote to wrote to President Joe Biden last week urging the administration to look into possible price-gouging by global shipping providers.
This is corporations padding their pockets and rewarding their stockholders at the expense of ordinary people," Warnock told Insider at the US Capitol.
"They're clearly, it seems to me, exploiting the pandemic," Warnock said Wednesday, adding that many of the companies in question "are not American."

The menu includes trimming gas taxes, prescription drug costs, and shipping fees.
